results.title: Three trains north
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
Journey out to the last frontier on three separate trains. First on the Gulflander, described as “heroic,” even “eccentric,” traversing Australia’s most isolated savannah country. Meet the characters who operate it, those who travel the line and the locals who depend on “one of the great little railroads of the world.” Then, travel to the heartland of Queensland from Brisbane to Longreach, the birthplace of the oldest and safest operating airline in the English speaking world. Hear stories of how the Spirit of the Outback has affected the lives of drovers, bush poets and swaggies. Finally, discover a train without a schedule, the Savannah Lander. Journey to the tropical outback and see old gold fields and the largest lava tube system on Earth, Undara.

results.title: Collected stories of the XPT
results.creator_credit: Cathy Beitz, Kath McIntryre and Banksia Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
On the Express Passenger Train, experience the fastest form of land transport between Australia’s two major capital cities, Melbourne and Sydney. Reaching speeds up to 70 miles per hour, the XPT travels across rolling plains and through the country’s Great Dividing Range. See rural areas rich with the history of early settlers who continued the struggles they imported from England and Ireland, including the outlaw, Ned Kelly. Visit the border town of Albury and find out about Australia’s unique railroad history. The town of Goulburn, home to the largest jail in the Southern Hemisphere, offers an insight into modern Aboriginal history. The view out the window of this train reveals a hundred fascinating observations about Australia and it’s people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cathy Beitz, Kath McIntryre and Banksia Productions

results.title: The Indian Pacific
results.creator_credit: Ron Bollman, Cathy Beitz and Banksia Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
Traverse the full distance between the Indian and Pacific Oceans, from Sydney to Perth, in a 2,700 mile odyssey. One of the world’s great long distance trains, the Indian Pacific, rolls across Australia like a miniature city on wheels, illuminating the colorful and quirky history, cultures and countryside of Australia as it goes. The heart of the Outback emerges in the Nullarbor Plain, offering a glimpse into the oldest continuing culture on earth. We stop several times along the way and meet the people who have made the remote outback their home. The three day journey on Australia’s crown jewel of rail lines promises all that the country itself has to offer - vivid landscapes, exotic creatures, mystical destinations, and unforgettable characters. Presented in two parts: Sydney to Adelaide and Adelaide to Perth.

results.title: On Paper
results.creator_credit: Andrew Scollo, Michael Bongiovanni, Ray Harris, Robert Lindsay, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
The connecting link in this video is photography, and the different approaches Micky Allan, Sally Robinson, Mandy Martin and Jenny Watson have to producing works on paper using photography either directly or indirectly

results.title: A Hundred-Odd Years From Now
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Australian Dried Fruits Association and Film House Company
results.brief_description: An advertising film with a difference: Into a strange computerised future where women “run things” by controlling huge colourful computers that go bleep booble bob bob ping etc, comes Yockoo, the boy from the bush, with his satchel of dried fruits. Slowly the women overcome their cold, futuristic ways in light of Yockoo’s size, shape and overall manliness. Eventually they unearth their deep feminine sexuality and cook Yockoo a feast of dried fruit dishes using cooking utensils from their local museum. Music by Frank Smith, Photographed by Lars Gundlach, Written and designed by Weatherhead & Stitt.

results.title: The Cave: a parable told by Orson Welles
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, C B Wismar, Nick Bosustow and Counterpoint Films
results.brief_description: An animated dramatization based on “The Allegory of the Cave” from Book 7 of Plato’s “Republic” illustrating mankind’s escape from the world of illusion to the world of reality. Four men chained in a cave take images reflected on a wall for the truth. Narrated by Orson Welles.

results.title: Birth without knives
results.brief_description:
Please note: This film contains footage of a home birth, including nudity.

Created by ‘Asphyxia’, this film talks about the concerns regarding pregnancy, avoiding a caesarean birth and having a home birth.

Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’.

results.title: The Naked Artist
results.creator_credit: Robert Rosmarin and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop Telling Tales. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.
Robert Rosmarin talks of the sometimes chaotic family-life of his childhood, reaching a climax with a tragic car accident which claimed the life of his mother. He talks about his on and off relationship with art, including participating in Spencer Tunick’s iconic crowd nude photographs taken on Princes Bridge in Melbourne.

results.title: The Crying Game
results.creator_credit: John Wood and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop Telling Tales. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.
This story made by John Wood talks about his uncontrallable bouts of crying. This is sometimes brought about by depression or anxiety. He has learned that the expression of emotion is very healthy.
